prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our continuum survey will be complete down to dust masses of 2*10^(-3) M_Jup (or 0.7 M–earth), which corresponds to a 5-sigma 1.3mm flux of 0.5 mJy at 175 pc. Thus we require an RMS of 0.1 mJy to achieve our science goal. For the aggregate bandwidth of 4.10 GHz of our spectral setup, this corresponds to an integration time of 3.08 minutes per source. For a total of 46 sources this amounts to 4.4 hours including overheads (we have essentially doubled the aggregate continuum bandwidth from the standard Band 6b setup by putting both the 13CO and C18O lines in the same baseband).
Even though the exposure time are driven by the main continuum science goal, this integration times will result 0.56 K sensitivity in the highest-resolution velocity channels (0.08 km*s-1} resolution of the 12CO(2-1) line). Typical 12CO(2-1) peak brightness temperatures of protoplanetary disks are larger than 1.5~K, thus we expect to detect the lines with a SNR 3 in the highest-resolution velocity channels.
We will increase the SN by binning to ~0.4-0.5 km*s-1 resolution, which is largely sufficient for detecting any kinematical structure (the high-velocity resolution is due to correlator restrictions). The typical line widths for Keplerian disks are of ~5-10 km*s-1, meaning they will be finely sampled and fall largely within even the smaller spectral window bandwidth.
Our disk radiative transfer model of a disk with 2*10^(-3) M_Jup, 200 AU radius at 175 pc, shows it will be detected in 12CO(2-1) with 120 mJy peaks per beam in 0.4 km*s-1 channels, so detected over a 5-sigma level throughout (Figure 2). The 230~GHz continuum emission from this disk model also reproduces the 0.5 mJy fiducial flux.
At the distance range of 150-200 pc, the requested ~0.9'' resolution is well matched to the typical disk sizes of 150-300 AU in radius (1-2 arcseconds in radius). We do not aim at resolving the dust disks, but for some bright, CO disk can be resolved (which are larger than the dust disks, Figure 2), we may obtain a few resolution elements across the disk which can be used to measure the disk sizes. CASA simulations of a standard disk model show that imaging is not a problem in the snapshot observations, as CLEAN can easily recover the model flux. Our sources are smaller than 1/3 of the primary beam, and hence do not need use of the ACA.
Instead of using the standard Band 6b spectral configuration to cover all CO(2-1) isotopologues (ALMA Technical Handbook Table~5.1), we have essentially doubled the aggregate continuum bandwidth from the standard Band 6b setup by putting both the 13CO and C18O lines in the same baseband. That allowed to free an entire second 2-GHz baseband for continuum, optimizing our continuum sensitivity without loosing sensitivity to the CO lines.
This configuration allows to cover all desired spectral lines and a continuum windows, providing a good compromise between number of lines sampled, spectral resolution, and total bandwidth to achieve the science goals in relatively short integration times.
No special calibrations are needed. No special bandpass accuracy is needed.
All sources are located within 10~degrees so they can all share the same calibrations, making this a time-efficient project.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Lupus Clouds, at 150-200~pc are one of the nearest southern star forming region. They are rich in young, pre-main sequence optically thick disks (Class II), which at typical ages of a few Myr are thought to the be sites of planet formation. Contrary to their more northerly counterparts (Taurus, Ophiucus) the Lupus clouds have been poorly studied in submm wavelengths (which trace the bulk of the disk mass). We propose to carry out a Band 6 snapshot survey of the disk population in the Lupus 1, 2, 3 and 4 clouds in order to derive the disk mass function for the cloud, determine the relative evolutionary stages of the disks, and compare these properties to other more well-studied clouds in the north. We will target both the dust continuum and CO(2-1) emission to obtain independent dust and gas masses and compute the dust to gas mass ratios. This project is part of the SOLA collaboration, a long-term program aimed at characterizing star and planet formation in the Lupus clouds with ALMA and other southern observatories.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
